awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: AGeS2 (Awards for Geochronology Student research) Program: Democratizing access to geochronology and promoting interdisciplinary science
awd_abstract_narration:
Geochronology is profoundly important in Earth science research. Geochronology data are required to quantitatively resolve the 4th dimension of time inherent in Earth science, and are increasingly necessary to conduct modern, cutting-edge, interdisciplinary research. The growing geochronology need is accompanied by strong demands to broaden community access to geochronology data, enhance the ability of laboratories to meet this pressure, and increase community awareness of how these data are produced and interpreted. The AGeS (Awards for Geochronology Student research) program provides opportunities for graduate students to develop the scientific rationale for projects involving geochronology, and then provides them with hands-on experience actually acquiring data in labs, all while being mentored by geochronologists. This project will grow AGeS2 into a wider cross-disciplinary initiative to further enhance access to geochronology data, promote geochronology training, and stimulate new synergistic science.
 
AGeS2 is aimed at 1) democratizing access to geochronology, 2) educating users of geochronology data, 3) promoting synergistic science by fostering new relationships between labs and other disciplines, and 4) providing strategic, high-quality, scientifically-valuable geochronology data for projects in which both users and producers of the data are intellectually engaged. It doubles the annual award funding for graduate student geochronology projects. A new partnership with the Geological Society of America (GSA) will allow successful management of this broader effort. AGeS2 will take advantage of new opportunities for cohort- and community building afforded by the program's popularity to maximize the educational and scientific outcomes of AGeS investments. These activities will include regular teleconferences with each year's AGeS student cohorts and two AGeS gatherings prior to the national GSA meeting. Ongoing student-lab-advisor interactions will be encouraged throughout the typical 2 year AGeS project duration to further promote project success.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview.

Geochronology is profoundly important in Earth science research. Geochronology data are required to quantitatively resolve the 4th dimension of time inherent in Earth science, and are increasingly necessary to conduct modern, cutting-edge, interdisciplinary research. The growing geochronology need is accompanied by strong demands to broaden community access to geochronology data, enhance the ability of laboratories to meet this pressure, and increase community awareness of how these data are produced and interpreted. Consequently, the 2012 National Research Council NROES report recommended: “EAR should explore new mechanisms for geochronology laboratories that will service the geochronology requirements of the broad suite of research opportunities while sustaining technical advances in methodologies.” The AGeS (Awards for Geochronology Student research) program provided a collaborative strategy for supporting access to geochronology data and the scientific expertise of lab personnel. The major goals of this project were to broaden access to geochronology, educate users of the data, promote synergistic science by fostering new relationships between labs, students, and scientists in different disciplines, and provide strategic, scientifically-valuable results for projects in which both the users and producers of the data are intellectually engaged.

Intellectual Merit.

AGeS2 was a competitive grant program that offered graduate students up to $10,000 to visit geochronology labs for a week or more to be trained in geochronology data acquisition and be mentored by geochronologists on a project of joint interest. These awards fill an important funding gap between small ($1-3k) student research grant opportunities (e.g., GSA student research grants) and large (>$100k) NSF grants), and can be sufficient to acquire a publishable dataset, catalyze new collaborations, and provide the foundation for future larger proposals.

In 2022, AGeS also developed and piloted the DiG (Diversity in Geochronology) program with the goal of generating and testing innovative ideas to expand geochronology access for those underrepresented in the Earth sciences. This program offered awards of up to $15,000 for projects that engage underrepresented students in geochronology.

Broader Impacts.

AGeS2 saw 196 student proposals submitted by graduate students over 3 proposal cycles, funded 52 new interdisciplinary projects between students and labs at an average award amount of $8,248, and currently counts >100 geochronology personnel associated with 64 labs in the AGeS partner lab pool. Each year this funding oppor­tunity has provided a concrete deadline to motivate new connections between geochro­nology data users and experts to discuss and tune ideas for cross-disciplinary research. Through this process, hundreds have been involved in AGeS proposals. During each graduate student proposal cycle, feedback was provided on every submitted proposal by a 10-member review committee. AGeS personnel also held annual virtual meetings with each funded cohort of AGeS awardees.

AGeS-DiG projects engage, train, and educate students at any level (including undergraduate and community college) who have not traditionally had equal access to opportunities to be trained in geochronology methods. In its pilot proposal cycle, DiG saw 16 submitted proposals and funded 6 projects at an average award amount of $14,350.

The AGeS program has grown to represent a loose consortium of 64 U.S. partner labs and >100 affiliated geo­chronologists, consisting mostly of individ­ual-investigator based facilities that contain the majority of the geochronology technical infrastructure distributed across the U.S. Any lab in the United States or its territories can become an AGeS lab by providing a 1-2-page lab profile that is posted on the AGeS lab database page to help geochronology users connect with potential host facilities. The list of partner labs on the AGeS web­site offers a key informational resource to connect geochronology data con­sumers and producers. For each lab, infor­mation about instrumentation, training, sam­ple preparation, analysis, analytical rates, and contact personnel is provided.

AGeS program assessment included multiple surveys of AGeS awardees, host labs, and home institution project supervisors. Feedback via this mechanism, as well as through discussion with the proposal review panel, was used to help refine the AGeS proposal process each year.

In October 2022, AGeS held a 1.5-day workshop that gathered 8 AGeS team members, 10 invited speakers, 19 AGeS awardees, and 16 attendees from the broader community. The symposium included presentations by invited experts about the latest developments in technique, analysis, applications, and geoscience results, as well as updates from AGeS awardees about their projects. Time during the workshop was also devoted to broader discussions about community needs for geochronology and feedback on the AGeS program.
